column1: #Text=The BLEBeacon dataset is a collection of Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE)  advertisement packets/traces generated from BLE beacons carried by people following their daily routine inside a university building for a whole month.
#Text=A network of Raspberry Pi 3 (RPi)-based edge devices were deployed inside a multi-floor facility continuously gathering BLE advertisement packets and storing them in a cloud-based environment.

#Text=The focus is on presenting a real-life realization of a location-aware sensing infrastructure, that can provide insights for smart sensing platforms, crowd-based applications, building management, and user-localization frameworks.
#Text=Since 2019, the BLEBeacon dataset is part of the Community Resource for Archiving Wireless Data At Dartmouth (CRAWDAD): https://crawdad.org/unm/blebeacon/20190312/
#Text=> Dimitrios Sikeridis, Ioannis Papapanagiotou, Michael Devetsikiotis, CRAWDAD dataset unm/blebeacon (v. 2019‑03‑12), downloaded from https://crawdad.org/unm/blebeacon/20190312, Mar 2019
#Text=Users carried off-the-shelf Gimbal Series 10 iBeacons that continuously transmit BLE advertisement packets.
#Text=The periodic transmission rate for each beacon is set to 1 Hz, with omni-directional antenna propagation setting, and transmission power of 0 dBm.
#Text=The backbone of the system is a network of Raspberry Pi 3 (RPi), able to collect all generated packets.
#Text=Regarding system operation two approaches were utilized in parallel:

#Text=* RSSI Report: all advertisement packet receptions from beacon devices are directly reported to a server with a message that contains the beacon/user ID, the packet's Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI), a reception timestamp, and finally the ID of the RPi that received the advertisement (Fig. 1).
#Text=* Check-In/Check-Out Report: each RPi scanner continuously manages a list of current occupants/users in its proximity.
#Text=A check in-timestamp is created during the user's initial entry, and while this beacon is still being detected by the RPi, a last seen-timestamp is updated.

#Text=When the beacon is no longer detected a Check-In/Check-Out report packet is created and sent to the server containing the beacon/user ID, the check in-timestamp, the last seen-timestamp, and finally the ID of the RPi (Fig. 2).
#Text=A thirty-second period is used to ensure that the occupant exited the RPi proximity.

#Text=The BLEBeacon dataset contains two files, one with the trial readings from the RSSI report operation (RSSI Report file) and the other from the Check-In/Check-Out report operation (Check-In Check-Out Report file).
#Text=The RSSI Report file contains the following entries:
#Text=* Entry_id: unique identifier of a packet in the dataset.
#Text=* Beacon_id: unique identifier of the occupant/beacon.
#Text=* RSSI: the Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) in dB.
#Text=* Timestamp: Date (Month/Day/Year) and Unix time (Hour:Second) of the advertisement packet reception moment from the Rpi.
#Text=* RPi_id: RPi that received the packet.
#Text=The Check-In/Check-Out Report file contains Entry_id, Beacon_id, and RPi_id as described above with the addition of two entries namely:
#Text=* In_time: Date (Month/Day/Year) and Unix time (Hour:Second) of the moment a user enters the RPi's vicinity and the first advertisement packet is received.
#Text=* Out_time: Date (Month/Day/Year) and Unix time (Hour:Second) of the last advertisement packet received from the same user by the specific RPi
#Text=Further information and a detailed description of the sensing infrastructure setup, the real-subject trial, and the BLEBeacon dataset can be found in: D.
#Text=Devetsikiotis,  ["BLEBeacon: A Real-Subject Trial Dataset from Mobile Bluetooth Low Energy Beacons"](https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.08782), arXiv preprint arXiv:1802.08782, 2018.
